**Czech** ([/ˈtʃɛk/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"); _čeština_
Czech pronunciation: [[ˈt͡ʃɛʃcɪna]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Czech "Help:IPA/Czech")),
historically also **Bohemian**[6] ([/boʊˈhiːmiən, bə-/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English");[7] _lingua Bohemica_ in [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin")), is
a [West Slavic language](/wiki/West_Slavic_language "West Slavic language") of
the [Czech–Slovak group](/wiki/Czech-Slovak_languages "Czech-Slovak
languages"),[6] which is extensively influenced by [Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin")[8] and [German](/wiki/German_language "German language").[9] Spoken
by over 10 million people, it serves as the official language of the [Czech
Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic"). Czech is closely related to
[Slovak](/wiki/Slovak_language "Slovak language"), to the point of [mutual
intelligibility](/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility "Mutual intelligibility") to a
very high degree.[10]

The Czecho-Slovak group developed within West Slavic in the [high
medieval](/wiki/High_medieval "High medieval") period, and the standardisation
of Czech and Slovak within the Czech–Slovak dialect continuum emerges in the
early modern period. In the later 18th to mid-19th century, the modern written
standard became codified in the context of the [Czech National
Revival](/wiki/Czech_National_Revival "Czech National Revival"). The main
vernacular, known as Common Czech, is based on the vernacular of
[Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague"), but is now spoken throughout most of the
Czech Republic. The [Moravian dialects](/wiki/Moravian_dialects "Moravian
dialects") spoken in the eastern part of the country are also classified as
Czech, although some of their eastern variants are closer to Slovak.

Czech has a moderately-sized phoneme inventory, comprising five vowels (each
[short or long](/wiki/Vowel_length "Vowel length")) and twenty-five consonants
(divided into "hard", "neutral" and "soft" categories). Words may contain
uncommon (or complicated) consonant clusters, including [one
consonant](/wiki/Raised_alveolar_trill "Raised alveolar trill") represented by
the [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme") _[ř](/wiki/%C5%98 "Ř")_ , or lack
vowels altogether. Czech uses a simple [orthography](/wiki/Orthography
"Orthography") which [phonologists](/wiki/Phonology "Phonology") have used as
a model.

##
Classification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Classification")]

Further information: [Czech-Slovak languages](/wiki/Czech-Slovak_languages
"Czech-Slovak languages") and [West Slavic](/wiki/West_Slavic "West Slavic")

[![Language-tree
graph](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Slavic_languages_tree.svg/350px-
Slavic_languages_tree.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Slavic_languages_tree.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Slavic_languages_tree.svg "Enlarge")

Classification of Czech within the [Balto-Slavic](/wiki/Balto-Slavic_languages
"Balto-Slavic languages") branch of the Indo-European language family. Czech
and Slovak make up a "Czech–Slovak" subgroup.

Czech is a member of the [West Slavic](/wiki/West_Slavic_languages "West
Slavic languages") sub-branch of the [Slavic](/wiki/Slavic_languages "Slavic
languages") branch of the [Indo-European](/wiki/Indo-European_languages "Indo-
European languages") language family. This branch includes
[Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language"),
[Kashubian](/wiki/Kashubian_language "Kashubian language"),
[Upper](/wiki/Upper_Sorbian "Upper Sorbian") and [Lower
Sorbian](/wiki/Lower_Sorbian "Lower Sorbian") and
[Slovak](/wiki/Slovak_language "Slovak language"). Slovak is the closest
language genetic neighbor of Czech, followed by Polish and Silesian.[11]

The West Slavic languages are spoken in Central Europe. Czech is distinguished
from other West Slavic languages by a more-restricted distinction between
"hard" and "soft" consonants (see Phonology below).[11]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

[![A Gothic-style book with ornate, flowery designs on the
cover](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Kralice.jpg/150px-
Kralice.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kralice.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kralice.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Bible of Kralice](/wiki/Bible_of_Kralice "Bible of Kralice") was the
first complete [translation of the Bible into the Czech
language](/wiki/Bible_translations_into_Czech "Bible translations into Czech")
from the original languages. Its six volumes were first published between 1579
and 1593.

Main article: [History of the Czech
language](/wiki/History_of_the_Czech_language "History of the Czech language")

See also: [History of the Czech lands](/wiki/History_of_the_Czech_lands
"History of the Czech lands")

### Medieval/Old
Czech[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Medieval/Old Czech")]

The term "Old Czech" is applied to the period predating the 16th century, with
the earliest records of the high medieval period also classified as "early Old
Czech", but it is also possible to speak simply about "Medieval Czech".

Around the 7th century, the [Slavic expansion](/wiki/Early_Slavs "Early
Slavs") reached Central Europe, settling on the eastern fringes of the
[Frankish Empire](/wiki/Frankish_Empire "Frankish Empire"). The West Slavic
polity of [Great Moravia](/wiki/Great_Moravia "Great Moravia") formed by the
9th century. The [Christianization of
Bohemia](/wiki/Christianization_of_Bohemia "Christianization of Bohemia") took
place during the 9th and 10th centuries. The diversification of the [Czech-
Slovak](/wiki/Czech-Slovak_languages "Czech-Slovak languages") group within
[West Slavic](/wiki/West_Slavic "West Slavic") began around that time, marked
among other things by its ephemeral use of the [voiced velar
fricative](/wiki/Voiced_velar_fricative "Voiced velar fricative") consonant
(/ɣ/)[12] and consistent stress on the first syllable.[13]

The Bohemian (Czech) language is first recorded in writing in glosses and
short notes during the 12th to 13th centuries. Literary works written in Czech
appear in the early 14th century and administrative documents first appear
towards the late 14th century. The first complete [Bible
translation](/wiki/Bible_translations_into_Czech "Bible translations into
Czech") also dates to this period.[14] Old Czech texts, including poetry and
cookbooks, were produced outside the university as well.[15]

Literary activity becomes widespread in the early 15th century in the context
of the [Bohemian Reformation](/wiki/Bohemian_Reformation "Bohemian
Reformation"). [Jan Hus](/wiki/Jan_Hus "Jan Hus") contributed significantly to
the standardization of [Czech orthography](/wiki/Czech_orthography "Czech
orthography"), advocated for widespread literacy among Czech commoners
(particularly in religion) and made early efforts to model written Czech after
the spoken language.[14]

### Early Modern
Czech[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Early Modern Czech")]

There was no standardization distinguishing between Czech and Slovak prior to
the 15th century.[16] In the 16th century, the division between Czech and
Slovak becomes apparent, marking the confessional division between Lutheran
Protestants in Slovakia using Czech orthography and Catholics, especially
Slovak Jesuits, beginning to use a separate Slovak orthography based on the
language of the [Trnava](/wiki/Trnava "Trnava") region.

The publication of the [Kralice Bible](/wiki/Kralice_Bible "Kralice Bible")
between 1579 and 1593 (the first complete Czech translation of the Bible from
the original languages) became very important for standardization of the Czech
language in the following centuries.

In 1615, the Bohemian diet tried to declare Czech to be the only official
language of the kingdom. After the [Bohemian Revolt](/wiki/Bohemian_Revolt
"Bohemian Revolt") (of predominantly Protestant aristocracy) which was
defeated by the [Habsburgs](/wiki/Habsburg "Habsburg") in 1620, the Protestant
intellectuals had to leave the country. This emigration together with other
consequences of the [Thirty Years' War](/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War "Thirty
Years' War") had a negative impact on the further use of the Czech language.
In 1627, Czech and German became official languages of the Kingdom of Bohemia
and in the 18th century German became dominant in Bohemia and Moravia,
especially among the upper classes.[17]

### Modern
Czech[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Modern Czech")]

[![In a detailed pencil sketch, a middle-aged man in a suit looks idly into
the
distance.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Jan_Vil%C3%ADmek_-
_Josef_Dobrovsk%C3%BD.jpg/220px-Jan_Vil%C3%ADmek_-
_Josef_Dobrovsk%C3%BD.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jan_Vil%C3%ADmek_-
_Josef_Dobrovsk%C3%BD.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jan_Vil%C3%ADmek_-_Josef_Dobrovsk%C3%BD.jpg "Enlarge")

[Josef Dobrovský](/wiki/Josef_Dobrovsk%C3%BD "Josef Dobrovský"), whose writing
played a key role in reviving Czech as a written language

See also: [Czech National Revival](/wiki/Czech_National_Revival "Czech
National Revival")

The modern standard Czech language originates in standardization efforts of
the 18th century.[18] By then the language had developed a literary tradition,
and since then it has changed little; journals from that period have no
substantial differences from modern standard Czech, and contemporary Czechs
can understand them with little difficulty.[19] Changes include the
[morphological](/wiki/Morphology_\(linguistics\) "Morphology \(linguistics\)")
shift of _í_ to _ej_ and _é_ to _í_ (although _é_ survives for some uses) and
the merging of _í_ and the former _ejí_.[20] Sometime before the 18th century,
the Czech language abandoned a distinction between phonemic /l/ and /ʎ/ which
survives in Slovak.[21]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/NTK_prohibition_signs.jpg/220px-
NTK_prohibition_signs.jpg)](/wiki/File:NTK_prohibition_signs.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NTK_prohibition_signs.jpg "Enlarge")

Prohibition signs written in Czech, by entry #3 into the building of National
Technical Library in Prague.

With the beginning of the national revival of the mid-18th century, Czech
historians began to emphasize their people's accomplishments from the 15th
through the 17th centuries, rebelling against the [Counter-
Reformation](/wiki/Counter-Reformation "Counter-Reformation") (the Habsburg
re-catholization efforts which had denigrated Czech and other
non-[Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language") languages).[22] Czech
[philologists](/wiki/Philology "Philology") studied sixteenth-century texts,
advocating the return of the language to [high culture](/wiki/High_culture
"High culture").[23] This period is known as the Czech National Revival[24]
(or Renaissance).[23]

During the national revival, in 1809 linguist and historian [Josef
Dobrovský](/wiki/Josef_Dobrovsk%C3%BD "Josef Dobrovský") released a German-
language grammar of Old Czech entitled _Ausführliches Lehrgebäude der
böhmischen Sprache_ (_Comprehensive Doctrine of the Bohemian Language_).
Dobrovský had intended his book to be
[descriptive](/wiki/Descriptive_linguistics "Descriptive linguistics"), and
did not think Czech had a realistic chance of returning as a major language.
However, [Josef Jungmann](/wiki/Josef_Jungmann "Josef Jungmann") and other
revivalists used Dobrovský's book to advocate for a Czech linguistic
revival.[24] Changes during this time included spelling reform (notably, _í_
in place of the former _j_ and _j_ in place of _g_), the use of _t_ (rather
than _ti_) to end infinitive verbs and the non-capitalization of nouns (which
had been a late borrowing from German).[21] These changes differentiated Czech
from Slovak.[25] Modern scholars disagree about whether the conservative
revivalists were motivated by nationalism or considered contemporary spoken
Czech unsuitable for formal, widespread use.[24]

Adherence to historical patterns was later relaxed and standard Czech adopted
a number of features from [Common Czech](/wiki/Common_Czech "Common Czech") (a
widespread, informal [register](/wiki/Register_\(sociolinguistics\) "Register
\(sociolinguistics\)")), such as leaving some proper nouns undeclined. This
has resulted in a relatively high level of homogeneity among all varieties of
the language.[26]

## Geographic
distribution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Geographic distribution")]

[](/wiki/File:Languages_of_CE_Europe.PNG "Enlarge")

A map of the languages of [Central](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and
[Eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe"). Within the Czech
Republic, Standard Czech is represented by dark yellow (C1) and [Moravian
dialects](/wiki/Moravian_dialects "Moravian dialects") by medium yellow (C2)
and light green (C3).

[![Map of Vojvodina, a province of Serbia, with Czech in official use in one
southeastern
municipality](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Vojvodina_rusyn_croatian_czech_map.png/220px-
Vojvodina_rusyn_croatian_czech_map.png)](/wiki/File:Vojvodina_rusyn_croatian_czech_map.png)

[](/wiki/File:Vojvodina_rusyn_croatian_czech_map.png "Enlarge")

Official use of Czech in [Vojvodina](/wiki/Vojvodina "Vojvodina"),
[Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia")

In 2005 and 2007, Czech was spoken by about 10 million residents of the [Czech
Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic").[17][27] A
[Eurobarometer](/wiki/Eurobarometer "Eurobarometer") survey conducted from
January to March 2012 found that the [first language](/wiki/First_language
"First language") of 98 percent of Czech citizens was Czech, the third-highest
in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (behind
[Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece") and [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary")).[28]

Czech, the official language of the Czech Republic (a member of the [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") since 2004), is one of the EU's
official languages and the 2012 Eurobarometer survey found that Czech was the
foreign language most often used in Slovakia.[28] Economist Jonathan van Parys
collected data on language knowledge in Europe for the 2012 [European Day of
Languages](/wiki/European_Day_of_Languages "European Day of Languages"). The
five countries with the greatest use of Czech were the [Czech
Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic") (98.77 percent),
[Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia") (24.86 percent),
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") (1.93 percent), [Poland](/wiki/Poland
"Poland") (0.98 percent) and [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") (0.47
percent).[29]

Czech speakers in Slovakia primarily live in cities. Since it is a recognised
[minority language](/wiki/Minority_language "Minority language") in Slovakia,
Slovak citizens who speak only Czech may communicate with the government in
their language to the extent that Slovak speakers in the Czech Republic may do
so.[30]

### United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: United States")]

See also: [Czech American](/wiki/Czech_American "Czech American") and [Czech
Texan](/wiki/Czech_Texan "Czech Texan")

Immigration of Czechs from Europe to the United States occurred primarily from
1848 to 1914. Czech is a [Less Commonly Taught
Language](/wiki/Less_Commonly_Taught_Languages "Less Commonly Taught
Languages") in U.S. schools, and is taught at Czech heritage centers. Large
communities of [Czech Americans](/wiki/Czech_American "Czech American") live
in the states of [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas"), [Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska
"Nebraska") and [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin "Wisconsin").[31] In the [2000
United States Census](/wiki/2000_United_States_Census "2000 United States
Census"), Czech was reported as the most-common [language spoken at
home](/wiki/Language_Spoken_at_Home_in_the_United_States_of_America "Language
Spoken at Home in the United States of America") (besides
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language")) in
[Valley](/wiki/Valley_County,_Nebraska "Valley County, Nebraska"),
[Butler](/wiki/Butler_County,_Nebraska "Butler County, Nebraska") and
[Saunders](/wiki/Saunders_County,_Nebraska "Saunders County, Nebraska")
[Counties](/wiki/County_\(United_States\) "County \(United States\)"),
Nebraska and [Republic County, Kansas](/wiki/Republic_County,_Kansas "Republic
County, Kansas"). With the exception of [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language
"Spanish language") (the non-English language most commonly spoken at home
nationwide), Czech was the most-common home language in over a dozen
additional counties in Nebraska, Kansas, Texas, [North
Dakota](/wiki/North_Dakota "North Dakota") and [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota
"Minnesota").[32] As of 2009, 70,500 Americans spoke Czech as their first
language (49th place nationwide, behind [Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language
"Turkish language") and ahead of [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish
language")).[33]

## Varieties[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Varieties")]

Further information: [Czech-Slovak languages](/wiki/Czech-Slovak_languages
"Czech-Slovak languages")

The main vernacular is "Common Czech", based on the dialect of the
[Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague") region. Other Bohemian dialects have become
marginalized, while [Moravian dialects](/wiki/Moravian_dialects "Moravian
dialects") remain more widespread, with a political movement for Moravian
linguistic revival active since the 1990s.

### Common
Czech[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Common Czech")]

The main Czech vernacular, spoken primarily near [Prague](/wiki/Prague
"Prague") but also throughout the country, is known as [Common
Czech](/wiki/Common_Czech "Common Czech") (_obecná čeština_). This is an
academic distinction; most Czechs are unaware of the term or associate it with
vernacular (or incorrect) Czech.[34] Compared to standard Czech, Common Czech
is characterized by simpler inflection patterns and differences in sound
distribution.[35]

Common Czech has become ubiquitous in most parts of the Czech Republic since
the later 20th century. It is usually defined as an
[interdialect](/wiki/Dachsprache "Dachsprache") used in common speech in
[Bohemia](/wiki/Bohemia "Bohemia") and western parts of
[Moravia](/wiki/Moravia "Moravia") (by about two thirds of all inhabitants of
the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic")). Common Czech is
not [codified](/wiki/Codification_\(linguistics\) "Codification
\(linguistics\)"), but some of its elements have become adopted in the written
standard. Since the second half of the 20th century, Common Czech elements
have also been spreading to regions previously unaffected, as a consequence of
media influence. Standard Czech is still the norm for politicians,
businesspeople and other Czechs in formal situations, but Common Czech is
gaining ground in journalism and the mass media.[35]

Common Czech is characterized by quite regular differences from the standard
[morphology](/wiki/Morphology_\(linguistics\) "Morphology \(linguistics\)")
and [phonology](/wiki/Phonology "Phonology"). These variations are more or
less common to all Common Czech [dialects](/wiki/Dialect "Dialect"):

  * _é_ usually replaced by _ý/í_ : mal**ý** město (small town), plam**í** nek (little flame), l**í** tat (to fly);
  * _ý_ (sometimes also _í_) replaced by _ej_ : mal**ej** dům (small house), ml**ej** n (mill), pl**ej** tvat (to waste), b**ej** t (to be) – as a consequence of the loss of the difference in the pronunciation of y/ý and i/í in the 15th century;
  * unified [plural](/wiki/Plural "Plural") [endings](/wiki/Ending_\(linguistics\) "Ending \(linguistics\)") of [adjectives](/wiki/Adjective "Adjective"): mal**ý** lidi (small people), mal**ý** ženy (small women), mal**ý** města (small towns) – stand.: malí lidé, malé ženy, malá města;
  * unified [instrumental](/wiki/Instrumental_case "Instrumental case") [ending](/wiki/Ending_\(linguistics\) "Ending \(linguistics\)") _-ma_ in [plural](/wiki/Plural "Plural"): s tě**ma** dobrej**ma** lid**ma** , žena**ma** , chlapa**ma** , města**ma** (with the good people, women, guys, towns) – stand.: s těmi dobrými lidmi, ženami, chlapy, městy (in essence, this form resembles the form of the [dual](/wiki/Dual_\(grammatical_number\) "Dual \(grammatical number\)"), which was once a productive form, but now is almost extinct, except a few examples; in Common Czech it can often be used indiscriminately, i.e. it can substitute a regular plural form, not just as it was once used);
  * prothetic _v-_ added to most words beginning _o-_ : **v** otevřít **v** okno (to open the window) – stand.: otevřít okno; but _ovoce_ not *_vovoce_ (fruit)
  * omitting of the syllabic _-l_ in the masculine ending of past tense verbs: řek (he said), moh (he could), pích (he pricked) – stand.: řekl, mohl, píchl.

### Bohemian
dialects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Bohemian dialects")]

Further information: [Chod dialect](/wiki/Chod_dialect "Chod dialect")

Apart from the Common Czech vernacular, there remain a variety of other
Bohemian dialect, mostly in marginal rural areas. Dialect use began to weaken
in the second half of the 20th century, and by the early 1990s dialect use was
stigmatized, associated with the shrinking lower class and used in literature
or other media for comedic effect. Increased travel and media availability to
dialect-speaking populations has encouraged them to shift to (or add to their
own dialect) standard Czech.[36] Although Czech has received considerable
scholarly interest for a Slavic language, this interest has focused primarily
on modern standard Czech and historical texts rather than dialects.[34]

The [Czech Statistical Office](/wiki/Czech_Statistical_Office "Czech
Statistical Office") in 2003 recognized the following Bohemian dialects:[37]

  * _Nářečí středočeská_ (Central Bohemian dialects)
  * _Nářečí jihozápadočeská_ (Southwestern Bohemian dialects)

    

  * _Podskupina chodská_ ([Chod](/wiki/Chod_dialect "Chod dialect") subgroup)
  * _Podskupina doudlebská_ ([Doudleby](/wiki/Doudleby "Doudleby") subgroup)

  * _Nářečí severovýchodočeská_ (Northeastern Bohemian dialects)

    

  * _Podskupina podkrknošská_ ([Krkonoše](/wiki/Krkono%C5%A1e "Krkonoše") subgroup)

### Moravian
dialects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Moravian dialects")]

Main article: [Moravian dialects](/wiki/Moravian_dialects "Moravian dialects")

Further information: [Lach dialects](/wiki/Lach_dialects "Lach dialects")

The Czech dialects spoken in [Moravia](/wiki/Moravia "Moravia") and
[Silesia](/wiki/Silesia "Silesia") are known as
[Moravian](/wiki/Moravian_dialects "Moravian dialects") (_moravština_). In the
[Austro-Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire "Austro-Hungarian
Empire"), "Bohemian-Moravian-Slovak" was a language citizens could register as
speaking (with German, Polish and several others).[38] Of the Czech dialects,
only Moravian is distinguished in nationwide surveys by the [Czech Statistical
Office](/wiki/Czech_Statistical_Office "Czech Statistical Office"). As of
2011, 62,908 Czech citizens spoke Moravian as their first language and 45,561
were [diglossal](/wiki/Diglossia "Diglossia") (speaking Moravian and standard
Czech as first languages).[39]

Beginning in the sixteenth century, some varieties of Czech resembled
Slovak;[16] the southeastern Moravian dialects, in particular, are sometimes
considered dialects of Slovak rather than Czech. These dialects form a
continuum between the Czech and Slovak languages,[40] using the same
declension patterns for nouns and pronouns and the same verb conjugations as
Slovak.[41]

The [Czech Statistical Office](/wiki/Czech_Statistical_Office "Czech
Statistical Office") in 2003 recognized the following Moravian dialects:[37]

  * _Nářečí českomoravská_ (Bohemian–Moravian dialects)
  * _Nářečí středomoravská_ (Central Moravian dialects)

    

  * _Podskupina tišnovská_ ([Tišnov](/wiki/Ti%C5%A1nov "Tišnov") subgroup)

  * _Nářečí východomoravská_ (Eastern Moravian dialects)

    

  * _Podskupina slovácká_ ([Moravian Slovak](/wiki/Moravian_Slovakia "Moravian Slovakia") subgroup)
  * _Podskupina valašská_ ([Moravian Wallachian](/wiki/Moravian_Wallachia "Moravian Wallachia") subgroup)

  * _Nářečí slezská_ (Silesian dialects)

### Sample[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Sample")]

In a 1964 textbook on Czech [dialectology](/wiki/Dialectology "Dialectology"),
Břetislav Koudela used the following sentence to highlight phonetic
differences between dialects:[42]

Standard Czech: | _D**ej** m**ou** k**u** z**e** m**lý** na na voz**í** k._  
---|---  
Common Czech: | _D**ej** m**ou** k**u** z**e** m**lej** na na voz**ej** k._  
Central Moravian: | _D**é** m**ó** k**u** z**e** m**lé** na na voz**é** k._  
Eastern Moravian: | _D**aj** m**ú** k**u** z**e** m**łý** na na voz**í** k._  
Silesian: | _D**aj** m**u** k**u** z**e** m**ły** na na voz**i** k._  
Slovak: | _D**aj** m**ú** ku z m**ly** na na voz**í** k._  
English: | Put the flour from the mill into the cart.  
  
### Mutual
intelligibility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Mutual intelligibility")]

Further information: [Comparison of Slovak and
Czech](/wiki/Comparison_of_Slovak_and_Czech "Comparison of Slovak and Czech")

Czech and Slovak have been considered [mutually
intelligible](/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility "Mutual intelligibility"); speakers
of either language can communicate with greater ease than those of any other
pair of West Slavic languages. Since the 1993 [dissolution of
Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Dissolution_of_Czechoslovakia "Dissolution of
Czechoslovakia"), mutual intelligibility has declined for younger speakers,
probably because Czech speakers now experience less exposure to Slovak and
vice versa.[43]

In phonetic differences, Czech is characterized by a [glottal
stop](/wiki/Glottal_stop "Glottal stop") before initial vowels and Slovak by
its less-frequent use of long vowels than Czech;[44] however, Slovak has long
forms of the consonants _r_ and _l_ when they function as vowels.[45] Phonemic
differences between the two languages are generally consistent, typical of two
dialects of a language. Grammatically, although Czech (unlike Slovak) has a
[vocative case](/wiki/Vocative_case "Vocative case"),[44] both languages share
a common syntax.[16]

One study showed that Czech and Slovak [lexicons](/wiki/Lexicon "Lexicon")
differed by 80 percent, but this high percentage was found to stem primarily
from differing orthographies and slight inconsistencies in morphological
formation;[46] Slovak morphology is more regular (when changing from the
[nominative](/wiki/Nominative_case "Nominative case") to the [locative
case](/wiki/Locative_case "Locative case"), _[Pra**h** a](/wiki/Prague
"Prague")_ becomes _Pra**z** e_ in Czech and _Pra**h** e_ in Slovak). The two
lexicons are generally considered similar, with most differences found in
colloquial vocabulary and some scientific terminology. Slovak has slightly
more borrowed words than Czech.[16]

The similarities between Czech and Slovak led to the languages being
considered a single language by a group of 19th-century scholars who called
themselves "Czechoslavs" (_Čechoslované_), believing that the peoples were
connected in a way which excluded [German Bohemians](/wiki/German_Bohemians
"German Bohemians") and (to a lesser extent)
[Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarian_people "Hungarian people") and other Slavs.[47]
During the [First Czechoslovak Republic](/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic
"First Czechoslovak Republic") (1918–1938), although "Czechoslovak" was
designated as the republic's official language, both Czech and Slovak written
standards were used. Standard written Slovak was partially modeled on literary
Czech, and Czech was preferred for some official functions in the Slovak half
of the republic. Czech influence on Slovak was protested by Slovak scholars,
and when Slovakia broke off from Czechoslovakia in 1938 as the [Slovak
State](/wiki/Slovak_Republic_\(1939%E2%80%931945\) "Slovak Republic
\(1939–1945\)") (which then aligned with [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany
"Nazi Germany") in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")),
literary Slovak was deliberately distanced from Czech. When the [Axis
powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers") lost the war and Czechoslovakia
reformed, Slovak developed somewhat on its own (with Czech influence); during
the [Prague Spring](/wiki/Prague_Spring "Prague Spring") of 1968, Slovak
gained independence from (and equality with) Czech,[16] due to the
transformation of Czechoslovakia from a unitary state to a federation. Since
the dissolution of Czechoslovakia in 1993, "Czechoslovak" has referred to
improvised [pidgins](/wiki/Pidgin "Pidgin") of the languages which have arisen
from the decrease in mutual intelligibility.[48]

## Vocabulary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Vocabulary")]

See also: [List of English words of Czech
origin](/wiki/List_of_English_words_of_Czech_origin "List of English words of
Czech origin")

Czech vocabulary derives primarily from Slavic, Baltic and other Indo-European
roots. Although most verbs have Balto-Slavic origins, pronouns, prepositions
and some verbs have wider, Indo-European roots.[49] Some loanwords have been
restructured by [folk etymology](/wiki/Folk_etymology "Folk etymology") to
resemble native Czech words
(_[hřbitov](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/h%C5%99bitov "wikt:hřbitov")_ ,
"graveyard" and _[listina](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/listina
"wikt:listina")_ , "list").[50]

Most Czech loanwords originated in one of two time periods. Earlier loanwords,
primarily from German,[51] [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") and
Latin,[52] arrived before the Czech National Revival. More recent loanwords
derive primarily from English and [French](/wiki/French_language "French
language"),[51] and also from [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew
language"), [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") and
[Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"). Many Russian loanwords,
principally animal names and naval terms, also exist in Czech.[53]

Although older German loanwords were colloquial, recent borrowings from other
languages are associated with high culture.[51] During the nineteenth century,
words with Greek and Latin roots were rejected in favor of those based on
older Czech words and common Slavic roots; "music" is
_[muzyka](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/muzyka "wikt:muzyka")_ in Polish and
_музыка_ (_muzyka_) in Russian, but in Czech it is
_[hudba](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hudba "wikt:hudba")_.[52] Some Czech
words have been borrowed as loanwords into
[English](/wiki/List_of_English_words_of_Czech_origin "List of English words
of Czech origin") and other languages—for example, _[robot](/wiki/Robot
"Robot")_ (from _[robota](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/robota
"wikt:robota")_ , "labor")[54] and _[polka](/wiki/Polka "Polka")_ (from
_[polka](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/polka "wikt:polka")_ ,
"[Polish](/wiki/Polish_people "Polish people") woman" or from "půlka"
"half").[55]

## Standard
Czech[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Standard Czech")]

The modern written standard is directly based on the standardisation during
the [Czech National Revival](/wiki/Czech_National_Revival "Czech National
Revival") in the 1830s, significantly influenced by [Josef
Jungmann](/wiki/Josef_Jungmann "Josef Jungmann")'s Czech-German dictionary
published during 1834–1839. Jungmann used vocabulary of the [Bible of
Kralice](/wiki/Bible_of_Kralice "Bible of Kralice") (1579–1613) period and of
the language used by his contemporaries. He borrowed words not present in
Czech from other Slavic languages or created neologisms.[56]

### Phonology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Phonology")]

Main article: [Czech phonology](/wiki/Czech_phonology "Czech phonology")

Czech contains ten basic [vowel](/wiki/Vowel "Vowel") [phonemes](/wiki/Phoneme
"Phoneme"), and three more found only in [loanwords](/wiki/Loanword
"Loanword"). They are /a/, /ɛ/, /ɪ/, /o/, and /u/, their long counterparts
/aː/, /ɛː/, /iː/, /oː/ and /uː/, and three diphthongs, /ou̯/, /au̯/ and /ɛu̯/.
The latter two diphthongs and the long /oː/ are exclusive to loanwords.[57]
Vowels are never reduced to [schwa](/wiki/Schwa "Schwa") sounds when
unstressed.[58] Each word usually has primary
[stress](/wiki/Stress_\(linguistics\) "Stress \(linguistics\)") on its first
[syllable](/wiki/Syllable "Syllable"), except for [enclitics](/wiki/Enclitic
"Enclitic") (minor, monosyllabic, unstressed syllables). In all words of more
than two syllables, every odd-numbered syllable receives secondary stress.
Stress is unrelated to vowel length, and the possibility of stressed short
vowels and unstressed long vowels can be confusing to students whose native
language combines the features (such as English).[59]

[Voiced](/wiki/Voice_\(phonetics\) "Voice \(phonetics\)")
[consonants](/wiki/Consonant "Consonant") with unvoiced counterparts are
unvoiced at the end of a word, or when they are followed by unvoiced
consonants.[60] Czech consonants are categorized as "hard", "neutral" or
"soft":

  * Hard: /d/, /ɡ/, /ɦ/, /k/, /n/, /r/, /t/, /x/
  * Neutral: /b/, /f/, /l/, /m/, /p/, /s/, /v/, /z/
  * Soft: /c/, /ɟ/, /j/, /ɲ/, /r̝/, /ʃ/, /ts/, /tʃ/, /ʒ/

This distinction describes the [declension](/wiki/Czech_declension "Czech
declension") patterns of nouns, which is based on the category of a noun's
ending consonant. Hard consonants may not be followed by _i_ or _í_ in
writing, or soft ones by _y_ or _ý_ (except in loanwords such as
_[kilogram](/wiki/Kilogram "Kilogram")_).[61] Neutral consonants may take
either character. Hard consonants are sometimes known as "strong", and soft
ones as "weak".[62]

The phoneme represented by the letter _[ř](/wiki/%C5%98 "Ř")_ (capital _Ř_) is
considered unique to Czech.[63] It represents the [raised alveolar non-
sonorant trill](/wiki/Raised_alveolar_non-sonorant_trill "Raised alveolar non-
sonorant trill") ([IPA](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet "International
Phonetic Alphabet"): [r̝]), a sound somewhere between Czech's _r_ and _ž_
(example: [![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Cs-%C5%99eka.ogg "About this sound") ["řeka"
(river)](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/45/Cs-%C5%99eka.ogg "Cs-
řeka.ogg") ([help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help "Wikipedia:Media
help")·[info](/wiki/File:Cs-%C5%99eka.ogg "File:Cs-řeka.ogg"))),[63] and is
present in _[Dvořák](/wiki/Dvo%C5%99%C3%A1k "Dvořák")_.

The consonants /r/ and /l/ can be [syllabic](/wiki/Syllabic_consonant
"Syllabic consonant"), acting as [syllable nuclei](/wiki/Syllable_nuclei
"Syllable nuclei") in place of a vowel. This can be difficult for non-native
speakers to pronounce, and _[Strč prst skrz krk](/wiki/Str%C4%8D_prst_skrz_krk
"Strč prst skrz krk")_ ("Stick [your] finger down [your] throat") is a Czech
[tongue twister](/wiki/Tongue_twister "Tongue twister").[64]

### Grammar[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Grammar")]

Slavic grammar is [fusional](/wiki/Fusional_language "Fusional language"); its
nouns, verbs, and adjectives are [inflected](/wiki/Inflection "Inflection") by
phonological processes to modify their meanings and grammatical functions, and
the easily separable [affixes](/wiki/Affix "Affix") characteristic of
[agglutinative](/wiki/Agglutinative_language "Agglutinative language")
languages are limited.[65] Slavic-language inflection is complex and
pervasive, inflecting for case, gender and number in nouns and tense, aspect,
[mood](/wiki/Grammatical_mood "Grammatical mood"), person and subject number
and gender in verbs.[66]

Parts of speech include adjectives, [adverbs](/wiki/Adverb "Adverb"), numbers,
[interrogative words](/wiki/Interrogative_word "Interrogative word"),
[prepositions](/wiki/Preposition "Preposition"),
[conjunctions](/wiki/Conjunction_\(grammar\) "Conjunction \(grammar\)") and
[interjections](/wiki/Interjection "Interjection").[67] Adverbs are primarily
formed by taking the final _ý_ or _í_ of an adjective and replacing it with
_e_ , _ě_ , or _o_.[68] Negative statements are formed by adding the affix
_[ne-](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ne#Czech "wikt:ne")_ to the verb of a
clause, with one exception: _je_ (he, she or it is) becomes _není_.[69]

#### Sentence and clause
structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Sentence and clause structure")]

See also: [Czech word order](/wiki/Czech_word_order "Czech word order")

Czech pronouns, [nominative case](/wiki/Nominative_case "Nominative case") Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1. | _já_ | _my_  
2. | _ty_  
_vy_ (formal) | _vy_  
3. | _on_ (masculine)  
_ona_ (feminine)  
_ono_ (neuter) | _oni_ (masculine)  
_ony_ (feminine)  
_ona_ (neuter)  
  
Because Czech uses [grammatical case](/wiki/Grammatical_case "Grammatical
case") to convey word function in a sentence (instead of relying on [word
order](/wiki/Word_order "Word order"), as English does), its word order is
flexible. As a [pro-drop language](/wiki/Pro-drop_language "Pro-drop
language"), in Czech an [intransitive](/wiki/Transitivity_\(grammar\)
"Transitivity \(grammar\)") sentence can consist of only a verb; information
about its subject is encoded in the verb.[70] Enclitics (primarily [auxiliary
verbs](/wiki/Auxiliary_verb "Auxiliary verb") and pronouns) must appear in the
second syntactic slot of a sentence, after the first stressed unit. The first
slot must contain a subject and object, a main form of a verb, an adverb or a
conjunction (except for the light conjunctions _a_ , "and", _i_ , "and even"
or _ale_ , "but").[71]

Czech syntax has a
[subject–verb–object](/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object
"Subject–verb–object") sentence structure. In practice, however, word order is
flexible and used for [topicalization](/wiki/Topicalization "Topicalization")
and focus. Although Czech has a [periphrastic](/wiki/Periphrasis
"Periphrasis") [passive](/wiki/Passive_voice "Passive voice") construction
(like English), colloquial word-order changes frequently produce the passive
voice. For example, to change "Peter killed Paul" to "Paul was killed by
Peter" the order of subject and object is inverted: _Petr zabil Pavla_ ("Peter
killed Paul") becomes "Paul, Peter killed" (_Pavla zabil Petr_). _Pavla_ is in
the [accusative case](/wiki/Accusative_case "Accusative case"), the
grammatical object (in this case, the victim) of the verb.[72]

A word at the end of a clause is typically emphasized, unless an upward
[intonation](/wiki/Intonation_\(linguistics\) "Intonation \(linguistics\)")
indicates that the sentence is a question:[73]

  * _Pes jí bagetu._ – The dog eats the baguette (rather than eating something else).
  * _Bagetu jí pes._ – The dog eats the baguette (rather than someone else doing so).
  * _Pes bagetu jí._ – The dog eats the baguette (rather than doing something else to it).
  * _Jí pes bagetu?_ – Does the dog eat the baguette? (emphasis ambiguous)

In portions of [Bohemia](/wiki/Bohemia "Bohemia") (including
[Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague")), questions such as _Jí pes bagetu?_ without
an interrogative word (such as _co_ , "what" or _kdo_ , "who") are
[intoned](/wiki/Intonation_\(linguistics\) "Intonation \(linguistics\)") in a
slow rise from low to high, quickly dropping to low on the last word or
phrase.[74]

In Czech syntax, adjectives precede nouns.[75] [Relative
clauses](/wiki/Relative_clause "Relative clause") are introduced by
[relativizers](/wiki/Relativizer "Relativizer") such as the adjective _který_
, analogous to the English [relative pronouns](/wiki/Relative_pronoun
"Relative pronoun") "which", "that", "who" and "whom". As with other
adjectives, it is declined into the appropriate case (see Declension below) to
match its associated noun, person and number. Relative clauses follow the noun
they modify, and the following is a [glossed](/wiki/Interlinear_gloss
"Interlinear gloss") example:[76]

**Czech:** | _Chc-i_ | _navštív-it_ | _univerzit-u,_ | _na_ | _kter-ou_ | _chod-í_ | _Jan._  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
**Gloss:** | want-1.SG | visit-[INF](/wiki/Infinitive "Infinitive") | university-SG.[ACC](/wiki/Accusative_case "Accusative case"), | on | which-SG.F.ACC | attend-3.SG | John.SG.NOM  
  
**English:** I want to visit the university that John attends.

####
Declension[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Declension")]

Main article: [Czech declension](/wiki/Czech_declension "Czech declension")

In Czech, nouns and adjectives are declined into one of seven grammatical
cases. Nouns are inflected to indicate their use in a sentence. A
[nominative–accusative language](/wiki/Nominative%E2%80%93accusative_language
"Nominative–accusative language"), Czech marks subject nouns with nominative
case and object nouns with accusative case. The genitive case marks possessive
nouns and some types of movement. The remaining cases (instrumental, locative,
vocative and dative) indicate semantic relationships, such as secondary
objects, movement or position ([dative case](/wiki/Dative_case "Dative case"))
and accompaniment (instrumental case). An adjective's case agrees with that of
the noun it describes. When Czech children learn their language's declension
patterns, the cases are referred to by number:[77]

No. | Ordinal name (Czech) | Full name (Czech) | Case | Main usage  
---|---|---|---|---  
1. | _první pád_ | _nominativ_ | [nominative](/wiki/Nominative_case "Nominative case") | Subjects  
2. | _druhý pád_ | _genitiv_ | [genitive](/wiki/Genitive_case "Genitive case") | Belonging, movement away from something (or someone)  
3. | _třetí pád_ | _dativ_ | [dative](/wiki/Dative_case "Dative case") | [Indirect objects](/wiki/Indirect_object "Indirect object"), movement toward something (or someone)  
4. | _čtvrtý pád_ | _akuzativ_ | [accusative](/wiki/Accusative_case "Accusative case") | [Direct objects](/wiki/Direct_object "Direct object")  
5. | _pátý pád_ | _vokativ_ | [vocative](/wiki/Vocative_case "Vocative case") | Addressing someone  
6. | _šestý pád_ | _lokál_ | [locative](/wiki/Locative_case "Locative case") | Location  
7. | _sedmý pád_ | _instrumentál_ | [instrumental](/wiki/Instrumental_case "Instrumental case") | Being used for a task; acting with someone (or something)  
  
Some Czech grammatical texts order the cases differently, grouping the
nominative and accusative (and the dative and locative) together because those
declension patterns are often identical; this order accommodates learners with
experience in other inflected languages, such as Latin or
[Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"). This order is
nominative, accusative, genitive, dative, locative, instrumental and
vocative.[77]

Some prepositions require the nouns they modify to take a particular case. The
cases assigned by each preposition are based on the physical (or metaphorical)
direction, or location, conveyed by it. For example,
_[od](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/od "wikt:od")_ (from, away from) and
_[z](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/z#Czech "wikt:z")_ (out of, off) assign
the genitive case. Other prepositions take one of several cases, with their
meaning dependent on the case; _[na](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/na#Czech
"wikt:na")_ means "onto" or "for" with the accusative case, but "on" with the
locative.[78]

Examples of declension patterns (using prepositions) for a few nouns with
adjectives follow. Only one plural example is given, since plural declension
patterns are similar across genders.

Case | Noun/adjective  
---|---  
Big dog (m.) | Small cat (f.) | Hard wood (n.) | Young dragons (pl.)  
Nom. | _velký pes_  
(big dog) | _malá kočka_  
(small cat) | _tvrdé dřevo_  
(hard wood) | _mladí draci_  
(young dragons)  
Gen. | _z velkého psa_  
(from the big dog) | _z malé kočky_  
(from the small cat) | _z tvrdého dřeva_  
(from the hard wood) | _z mladých draků_  
(from the young dragons)  
Dat. | _k velkému psovi_  
(to the big dog) | _k malé kočce_  
(to the small cat) | _ke tvrdému dřevu_  
(to the hard wood) | _ke mladým drakům_  
(to the young dragons)  
Acc. | _na velkého psa_  
(for the big dog) | _na malou kočku_  
(for the small cat) | _na tvrdé dřevo_  
(for the hard wood) | _na mladé draky_  
(for the young dragons)  
Voc. | _velký pse!_  
(big dog!) | _malá kočko!_  
(small cat!) | _tvrdé dřevo!_  
(hard wood!) | _mladí draci!_  
(young dragons!)  
Loc. | _o velkém psovi_  
(about the big dog) | _o malé kočce_  
(about the small cat) | _o tvrdém dřevě_  
(about the hard wood) | _o mladých dracích_  
(about the young dragons)  
Ins. | _s velkým psem_  
(with the big dog) | _s malou kočkou_  
(with the small cat) | _s tvrdým dřevem_  
(with the hard wood) | _s mladými draky_  
(with the young dragons)  
  
This is a glossed example of a sentence using several cases:

_Czech:_ | _Nes-l_ | _js-em_ | _krabic-i_ | _do_ | _dom-u_ | _se_ | _sv-ým_ | _přítel-em._  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
_Gloss:_ | carry-SG.M.PST | be-1.SG | box-SG.ACC | into | house-SG.GEN | with | own-SG.INS | friend-SG.INS  
  
_English:_ I carried the box into the house with my friend.

Czech distinguishes three [genders](/wiki/Grammatical_gender "Grammatical
gender")—masculine, feminine, and neuter—and the masculine gender is
subdivided into [animate](/wiki/Animacy "Animacy") and inanimate. With few
exceptions, feminine nouns in the nominative case end in _-a_ , _-e_ , or
_-ost_ ; neuter nouns in _-o_ , _-e_ , or _-í_ , and masculine nouns in a
consonant.[79] Adjectives agree in gender and animacy (for masculine nouns in
the accusative or genitive singular and the nominative plural) with the nouns
they modify.[80] The main effect of gender in Czech is the difference in noun
and adjective declension, but other effects include past-tense verb endings:
for example, _dělal_ (he did, or made); _dělala_ (she did, or made) and
_dělalo_ (it did, or made).[81]

Nouns are also inflected for [number](/wiki/Grammatical_number "Grammatical
number"), distinguishing between singular and plural. Typical of a Slavic
language, Czech cardinal numbers one through four allow the nouns and
adjectives they modify to take any case, but numbers over five place these
nouns and adjectives in the genitive case when the entire expression is in
nominative or accusative case. The [Czech koruna](/wiki/Czech_koruna "Czech
koruna") is an example of this feature; it is shown here as the subject of a
hypothetical sentence, and declined as genitive for numbers five and up.[82]

English | Czech  
---|---  
one crown | _jedna koruna_  
two crowns | _dvě koruny_  
three crowns | _tři koruny_  
four crowns | _čtyři koruny_  
five crowns | _pět korun_  
  
Numerical words decline for case and, for numbers one and two, for gender.
Numbers one through five are shown below as examples, and have some of the
most exceptions among Czech numbers. The number one has declension patterns
identical to those of the [demonstrative pronoun](/wiki/Demonstrative_pronoun
"Demonstrative pronoun"), _[to](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/to#Czech
"wikt:to")_.[83][84]

| 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5  
---|---|---|---|---|---  
Nominative | _jeden_ (male)  
_jedna_ (female)  
_jedno_ (neuter) | _dva_ (male)  
_dvě_ (female, neuter) | _tři_ | _čtyři_ | _pět_  
Genitive | _jednoho_ (male)  
_jedné_ (female)  
_jednoho_ (neuter) | _dvou_ | _tří_ | _čtyř_ | _pěti_  
Dative | _jednomu_ (male)  
_jedné_ (female)  
_jednomu_ (neuter) | _dvěma_ | _třem_ | _čtyřem_ | _pěti_  
Accusative | _jednoho_ (male an.)  
_jeden_ (male in.)  
_jednu_ (female)  
_jedno_ (neuter) | _dva_ (male)  
_dvě_ (female, neuter) | _tři_ | _čtyři_ | _pět_  
Locative | _jednom_ (male)  
_jedné_ (female)  
_jednom_ (neuter) | _dvou_ | _třech_ | _čtyřech_ | _pěti_  
Instrumental | _jedním_ (male)  
_jednou_ (female)  
_jedním_ (neuter) | _dvěma_ | _třemi_ | _čtyřmi_ | _pěti_  
  
Although Czech's [grammatical numbers](/wiki/Grammatical_number "Grammatical
number") are singular and [plural](/wiki/Plural "Plural"), several residuals
of [dual](/wiki/Dual_\(grammatical_number\) "Dual \(grammatical number\)")
forms remain. Some nouns for paired body parts use a historical dual form to
express plural in some cases: _[ruka](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ruka
"wikt:ruka")_ (hand)— _ruce_ (nominative);
_[noha](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noha "wikt:noha")_ (leg)— _nohama_
(instrumental), _nohou_ (genitive/locative);
_[oko](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/oko "wikt:oko")_ (eye)— _oči_ , and
_[ucho](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ucho "wikt:ucho")_ (ear)— _uši_. While
two of these nouns are neuter in their singular forms, all plural forms are
considered feminine; their gender is relevant to their associated adjectives
and verbs.[85] These forms are plural semantically, used for any non-singular
count, as in _mezi čtyřma očima_ (face to face, lit. _among four eyes_). The
plural number paradigms of these nouns are actually a mixture of historical
dual and plural forms. For example, _nohy_ (legs; nominative/accusative) is a
standard plural form of this type of noun.

#### Verb
conjugation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Verb conjugation")]

Main articles: [Czech conjugation](/wiki/Czech_conjugation "Czech
conjugation") and [Morphological classification of Czech
verbs](/wiki/Morphological_classification_of_Czech_verbs "Morphological
classification of Czech verbs")

Czech verb conjugation is less complex than noun and adjective declension
because it codes for fewer categories. Verbs agree with their subjects in
[person](/wiki/Grammatical_person "Grammatical person") (first, second or
third) and [number](/wiki/Grammatical_number "Grammatical number") (singular
or plural), and are conjugated for tense (past, present or
[future](/wiki/Future_tense "Future tense")). For example, the conjugated verb
_[mluvíme](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mluvit "wikt:mluvit")_ (we speak) is
in the present tense and first-person plural; it is distinguished from other
conjugations of the [infinitive](/wiki/Infinitive "Infinitive") _mluvit_ by
its ending, _me_.[86]

See also: [Grammatical aspect in Slavic
languages](/wiki/Grammatical_aspect_in_Slavic_languages "Grammatical aspect in
Slavic languages")

Typical of Slavic languages, Czech marks its verbs for one of two [grammatical
aspects](/wiki/Grammatical_aspect "Grammatical aspect"):
[perfective](/wiki/Perfective_aspect "Perfective aspect") and
[imperfective](/wiki/Imperfective_aspect "Imperfective aspect"). Most verbs
are part of inflected aspect pairs—for example,
_[koupit](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/koupit "wikt:koupit")_ (perfective)
and _[kupovat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/kupovat "wikt:kupovat")_
(imperfective). Although the verbs' meaning is similar, in perfective verbs
the action is completed and in imperfective verbs it is ongoing. This is
distinct from [past](/wiki/Past_tense "Past tense") and [present
tense](/wiki/Present_tense "Present tense"),[87] and any Czech verb of either
aspect can be conjugated into any of its three tenses.[86] Aspect describes
the state of the action at the time specified by the tense.[87]

The verbs of most aspect pairs differ in one of two ways: by prefix or by
suffix. In prefix pairs, the perfective verb has an added prefix—for example,
the imperfective _psát_ (to write, to be writing) compared with the perfective
_napsat_ (to write down, to finish writing). The most common prefixes are
_na-_ , _o-_ , _po-_ , _s-_ , _u-_ , _vy-_ , _z-_ and _za-_.[88] In suffix
pairs, a different infinitive ending is added to the perfective stem; for
example, the perfective verbs _koupit_ (to buy) and _prodat_ (to sell) have
the imperfective forms _kupovat_ and _prodávat_.[89] Imperfective verbs may
undergo further morphology to make other imperfective verbs (iterative and
[frequentative](/wiki/Frequentative "Frequentative") forms), denoting repeated
or regular action. The verb _jít_ (to go) has the iterative form _chodit_ (to
go repeatedly) and the frequentative form _chodívat_ (to go regularly).[90]

Many verbs have only one aspect, and verbs describing continual states of
being— _[být](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/b%C3%BDt "wikt:být")_ (to be),
_[chtít](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cht%C3%ADt "wikt:chtít")_ (to want),
_[moct](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/moct "wikt:moct")_ (to be able to),
_[ležet](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/le%C5%BEet "wikt:ležet")_ (to lie
down, to be lying down)—have no perfective form. Conversely, verbs describing
immediate states of change—for example,
_[otěhotnět](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ot%C4%9Bhotn%C4%9Bt
"wikt:otěhotnět")_ (to become pregnant) and _[nadchnout
se](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nadchnout_se "wikt:nadchnout se")_ (to
become enthusiastic)—have no imperfective aspect.[91]

Although Czech's use of present and future tense is largely similar to that of
English, the language uses past tense to represent the English [present
perfect](/wiki/Present_perfect "Present perfect") and [past
perfect](/wiki/Pluperfect "Pluperfect"); _ona běžela_ could mean _she ran_ ,
_she has run_ or _she had run_.[92]

Conjugation of _být_ in future tense Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1. | _budu_ | _budeme_  
2. | _budeš_ | _budete_  
3. | _bude_ | _budou_  
  
In some contexts, Czech's perfective present (which differs from the English
[present perfect](/wiki/Present_perfect "Present perfect")) implies future
action; in others, it connotes habitual action.[93] As a result, the language
has a proper future tense to minimize ambiguity. The future tense does not
involve conjugating the verb describing an action to be undertaken in the
future; instead, the future form of _být_ (as shown in the table at left) is
placed before the infinitive (for example, _budu jíst_ —"I will eat").[94]

This conjugation is not followed by _být_ itself, so future-oriented
expressions involving nouns, adjectives, or prepositions (rather than verbs)
omit _být_. "I will be happy" is translated as _Budu šťastný_ (not _Budu být
šťastný_).[94]

Conditional form of _[koupit](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/koupit "wikt:koupit")_ (to buy) Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1. | _koupil/a bych_ | _koupili/y bychom_  
2. | _koupil/a bys_ | _koupili/y byste_  
3. | _koupil/a/o by_ | _koupili/y/a by_  
  
The infinitive form ends in _t_ (archaically, _ti_). It is the form found in
dictionaries and the form that follows auxiliary verbs (for example, _můžu tě
slyšet_ —"I can _hear_ you").[95] Czech verbs have three [grammatical
moods](/wiki/Grammatical_mood "Grammatical mood"):
[indicative](/wiki/Indicative "Indicative"),
[imperative](/wiki/Imperative_mood "Imperative mood") and
[conditional](/wiki/Conditional_mood "Conditional mood").[96] The imperative
mood adds specific endings for each of three person (or number) categories:
_-Ø/-i/-ej_ for second-person singular, _-te/-ete/-ejte_ for second-person
plural and _-me/-eme/-ejme_ for first-person plural.[97] The conditional mood
is formed with a [particle](/wiki/Grammatical_particle "Grammatical particle")
after the past-tense verb. This mood indicates possible events, expressed in
English as "I would" or "I wish".[98]

Most Czech verbs fall into one of five
[classes](/wiki/Morphological_classification_of_Czech_verbs "Morphological
classification of Czech verbs"), which determine their conjugation patterns.
The future tense of _být_ would be classified as a Class I verb because of its
endings. Examples of the present tense of each class and some common irregular
verbs follow in the tables below:[99]

|  | Class I | Class II | Class III | Class IV | Class V  
---|---|---|---|---|---  
Definition | to carry | to print | to wander | to suffer | to do, to make  
Infinitive | _nést_ | _tisknout_ | _putovat_ | _trpět_ | _dělat_  
1st p. sg. | _nesu_ | _tisknu_ | _putuji_ | _trpím_ | _dělám_  
2nd p. sg. | _neseš_ | _tiskneš_ | _putuješ_ | _trpíš_ | _děláš_  
3rd p. sg. | _nese_ | _tiskne_ | _putuje_ | _trpí_ | _dělá_  
1st p. pl. | _neseme_ | _tiskneme_ | _putujeme_ | _trpíme_ | _děláme_  
2nd p. pl. | _nesete_ | _tisknete_ | _putujete_ | _trpíte_ | _děláte_  
3rd p. pl. | _nesou_ | _tisknou_ | _putují_ | _trpí_ | _dělají_  
Irregular verbs | Definition | to be | to want | to eat | to know  
---|---|---|---|---  
Infinitive | _být_ | _chtít_ | _jíst_ | _vědět_  
1st p. sg. | _jsem_ | _chci_ | _jím_ | _vím_  
2nd p. sg. | _jsi_ | _chceš_ | _jíš_ | _víš_  
3rd p. sg. | _je_ | _chce_ | _jí_ | _ví_  
1st p. pl. | _jsme_ | _chceme_ | _jíme_ | _víme_  
2nd p. pl. | _jste_ | _chcete_ | _jíte_ | _víte_  
3rd p. pl. | _jsou_ | _chtějí_ | _jedí_ | _vědí_  
  
###
Orthography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Orthography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Psac%C3%AD_p%C3%ADsmo.gif/300px-
Psac%C3%AD_p%C3%ADsmo.gif)](/wiki/File:Psac%C3%AD_p%C3%ADsmo.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Psac%C3%AD_p%C3%ADsmo.gif "Enlarge")

The handwritten Czech alphabet

Main article: [Czech orthography](/wiki/Czech_orthography "Czech orthography")

See also: [Czech Braille](/wiki/Czech_Braille "Czech Braille")

Czech has one of the most [phonemic orthographies](/wiki/Phonemic_orthography
"Phonemic orthography") of all European languages. Its thirty-one
[graphemes](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme") represent thirty sounds (in most
dialects, _i_ and _y_ have the same sound), and it contains only one
[digraph](/wiki/Digraph_\(orthography\) "Digraph \(orthography\)"): _ch_ ,
which follows _h_ in the alphabet.[100] As a result, some of its characters
have been used by phonologists to denote corresponding sounds in other
languages. The characters _q_ , _w_ and _x_ appear only in foreign words.[101]
The [háček](/wiki/H%C3%A1%C4%8Dek "Háček") (ˇ) is used with certain letters to
form new characters: _[š](/wiki/%C5%A0 "Š")_ , _[ž](/wiki/%C5%BD "Ž")_ , and
_[č](/wiki/%C4%8C "Č")_ , as well as _[ň](/wiki/%C5%87 "Ň")_ ,
_[ě](/wiki/%C4%9A "Ě")_ , _[ř](/wiki/%C5%98 "Ř")_ , _[ť](/wiki/%C5%A4 "Ť")_ ,
and _[ď](/wiki/%C4%8E "Ď")_ (the latter five uncommon outside Czech). The last
two letters are sometimes written with a comma above (ʼ, an abbreviated háček)
because of their height.[102] The character _ó_ exists only in loanwords and
[onomatopoeia](/wiki/Onomatopoeia "Onomatopoeia").[103]

Unlike most European languages, Czech distinguishes [vowel
length](/wiki/Vowel_length "Vowel length"); long vowels are indicated by an
[acute accent](/wiki/Acute_accent "Acute accent") or, occasionally with _ů_ ,
a [ring](/wiki/Ring_\(diacritic\) "Ring \(diacritic\)"). Long _u_ is usually
written _ú_ at the beginning of a word or morpheme (_úroda_ , _neúrodný_) and
_ů_ elsewhere,[104] except for loanwords (_skútr_) or onomatopoeia
(_bú_).[105] Long vowels and _ě_ are not considered separate letters.[106]

Czech [typographical](/wiki/Typography "Typography") features not associated
with phonetics generally resemble those of most [Latin](/wiki/Latin_script
"Latin script") European languages, including English. [Proper
nouns](/wiki/Proper_noun "Proper noun"), [honorifics](/wiki/Honorific
"Honorific"), and the first letters of quotations are
[capitalized](/wiki/Capitalization "Capitalization"), and
[punctuation](/wiki/Punctuation "Punctuation") is typical of other Latin
European languages. Writing of ordinal numerals is similar to most European
languages. The Czech language uses a decimal comma instead of a decimal point.
When writing a long number, spaces between every three numbers (e.g. between
hundreds and thousands) may be used for better orientation in handwritten
texts, but not in decimal places, like in English. The number 1,234,567.8910
may be written as 1234567,8910 or 1 234 567,8910. Ordinal numbers (1st) use a
point as in German (1.). In [proper noun](/wiki/Proper_noun "Proper noun")
phrases (except personal names), only the first word is capitalized (_Pražský
hrad_ , [Prague Castle](/wiki/Prague_Castle "Prague Castle")).[107][108]

### Sample
text[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Czech_language&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Sample text")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Presl_brambor.JPG/220px-
Presl_brambor.JPG)](/wiki/File:Presl_brambor.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Presl_brambor.JPG "Enlarge")

1846 sample of printed Czech

According to Article 1 of the United Nations [Universal Declaration of Human
Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of
Human Rights"):

Czech: _Všichni lidé se rodí svobodní a sobě rovní co do důstojnosti a práv.
Jsou nadáni rozumem a svědomím a mají spolu jednat v duchu bratrství._[109]

English: "All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They
are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a
spirit of brotherhood."[110]
